page.title: 08St.Margaret's Church History
page.content: St Margaret's Church at Carsington is of 12th century origin,but originally it church was probably wooden.The first stone building was erected in 1325 and rebuilt in 1648 repaired and reroofed in 1854.In 1873 the box pews were replaced with pine benches and wood from the box pews used as panelling around the walls.A porch was also built at this time.A parish had a rectory and its own Rector until an order in council dated 11th May 1922 approved a scheme for union of of the benifice of Carsington (being a rectory ) and the benifice (being a vicarage) of Wirksworth.The Reverend Herbet Ham being the then incumbant of the United Benifice. During the 1939- 45 war,for the sake of convenience, Carsington was temporairiy, under the incumbency of the vicar of Brassington ,reverting again to Wirksworth in 1951
